segments.key_quote: Lord Shri Krishna was not that type of incarnation. He was actually the personality of broadhead from the very beginning of his appearance.
segments.summary: The speaker establishes Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead from birth, contrasting this with modern, self-proclaimed incarnations.
segments.transcript: OM NAMO BADRAVATE VASUDEVAYA Reading from Srimad-Bhagavatam, 10-1, Chapter 1, Text No. 20 TRITVANTI LAKARMANI SAHARAMENA KESAVA ATIMARTYANI BADRAVAN GRUDA TRAPATAP MANUSAH Lord Shri Krishna, the personality of broadhead, along with Balram, played like a human being, and so must he perform. Many superhuman acts. The doctrines of anthropomorphism and zoomorphism are never applicable to Shri Krishna or the personality of broadhead. The theory that a man becomes broad by dint of penance and austerities is wrong. The theory that a man becomes broad is very much rampant nowadays, especially in India. Since Lord Rama, Lord Krishna, and Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu were detected by the sages and saints to be the personality of broadhead, as indicated in revealed scriptures, many unscrupulous men have created their own incarnations. This process of contracting an incarnation of God has become an ordinary business, especially in Bengal. Any popular personality with a few traits of mystic powers will displace some feet of jugglery and easily become an incarnation of God by popular vote. Lord Shri Krishna was not that type of incarnation. He was actually the personality of broadhead from the very beginning of his appearance. He appeared before his so-called mother, as four-armed Vishnu. Then, at the request of the mother, he became like a human child and at once left her for another devotee at Grotul, where he was accepted as the son of Nanda Maharaj and Yasoda Mata. Similarly, Shri Baladeva, the counterpart of Lord Shri Krishna, was also considered a human child, born of the mother of Lord Krishna. segments.key_quote: So, knowledge of the transcendental nature of the birth and deeds of Lord Shri Krishna is sufficient for liberation.
segments.summary: Knowing Krishna's transcendental nature leads to liberation, as described in the Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.transcript: born of another wife of Shri Vasudeva. In the Bhagavad Gita, the Lord says that his birth and deeds are transcendental and that anyone who is so fortunate as to know the transcendental nature of his birth and deeds will at once become liberated and eligible to return to the kingdom of God. So, knowledge of the transcendental nature of the birth and deeds of Lord Shri Krishna is sufficient for liberation. In Bhagavatam, the transcendental nature of the Lord is described in nine cantos and in the tenth canto, his specific pastimes are taken up. All this becomes known as one's reading of this literature progresses. It is important to note here, however, that the Lord exhibited his divinity even from the lap of his mother, that his deeds were all superhuman, that he lifted the Jordan Hill at the age of seven, and that all these acts definitely prove him to be actually the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Yet, due to his mystic reverence, he was always accepted as an ordinary human child by his so-called father and mother and other relatives. Whenever some Herculean task was performed by him, they did not accept it otherwise, and they remained satisfied with unflinching filial love for their son. As such, the sage of Naimisaranya described him as apparently resembling a human being, but actually, he is the Supreme,

segments.key_quote: So our purpose is to come to Krishna to see what I can give, not what I can take.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the importance of giving to Krishna and seeking His pleasure, explaining that true enjoyment comes from being part of Krishna's enjoyment.

Taking back subtle happiness, subtle pleasure. I'm giving money. So in one sense I'm charity. I'm giving away one lakh rupees. My bank balance is less by one lakh. I'm giving it. For what? This is a core misunderstanding we all have. Sometimes many years it takes to understand this. But that's the crux of the point. Chanting Hare Krishna is not for my happiness.
